page.title: 06FARMING IN THE BRAES
page.content: With all the land in the Braes at over 1000 feet above sea level, the farmers have a hard task raising cattle and sheep. The winters are severe with movement usually hampered by deep snow. Most cattle are housed from November till April but the sheep are outside all year. All the animals have to be fed with hay or silage which is conserved during the short summer. The main crop is grass, with turnips and barley grown for winter feed, and fodder rape to fatten lambs which spend the summer on the hills. The cows rear their own calves and these are sold at about 1 year old in the store market at Tomintoul, Elgin, Dufftown or Huntly. Lambs are born in April and May and these are sold from September onwards with the farmer retaining the ewe lambs to enter the breeding flock.
